title: 110_s2902
content: The "Independent Office of Advocacy and Small Business Regulatory Reform Act of 2008" aims to provide adequate financial resources for the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration to advocate for small businesses, authorize separate appropriations for the Office, and enhance its role as outlined in title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY amended to carry out responsibilities under chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. Budgetary line item and authorization of appropriations updated in Title II of Public Law 94-305. The President's budget must include a separate statement for appropriations for the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration is responsible for providing the Office of Advocacy with necessary office space, equipment, and budget. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out these responsibilities. The President's budget must include a separate statement for appropriations for the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. Any amount appropriated under this subsection shall remain available without fiscal year limitation until expended. SEC. 4. REGULATORY FLEXIBILITY REFORM FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. The text discusses requirements for more detailed analyses in regulatory flexibility for small businesses. It includes notifying the Small Business Administration of draft rules with significant economic impact on small entities and outlines the process for submission and publication of these rules by agencies. The final regulatory flexibility analysis includes responding to comments on the certification of proposed rules and comments filed by the chief counsel for advocacy. The agency must publish any initial regulatory flexibility analysis on its website. Additionally, the final regulatory flexibility analysis must include responses to comments from the Chief Counsel for Advocacy and any changes made to the proposed rule as a result of those comments. The agency must make the final regulatory flexibility analysis available to the public on its website and in the Federal Register. Additionally, cross-references to other required analyses are allowed to fulfill content requirements. Section 607 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include quantification requirements for agencies when complying with sections 603 and 604. Agencies must provide a quantifiable description of the effects of proposed or final rules, or explain in detail why quantification is not feasible. Section 605 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to address incorporations by reference and certifications. The table of sections for chapter 6 is also updated accordingly. Section 605 of title 5, United States Code is amended to address incorporations by reference and certifications. Additionally, section 607 is updated to include quantification requirements. SEC. 5 introduces oversight of regulatory enforcement. Section 30 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 657) is amended to clarify that agencies must provide relevant information to the Ombudsman upon request. Amendment to Section 30 of the Small Business Act requires agencies to provide information to the Ombudsman upon request and outlines procedures for handling substantiated comments and reporting on enforcement activities to Congress and affected agencies. The amendment to Section 30 of the Small Business Act mandates agencies to report on their enforcement activities to the Ombudsman, coordinate with the Ombudsman for hearings, and ensure coordination on official correspondence with the Ombudsman.
